Situation1: There is a scheduled family gathering on the calendar.
Situation2: Many prospects ask detailed technical questions about the new service that the script only partially addresses.
Story: I glance at the calendar on my phone, the bright red circle around “Family Gathering” staring back at me. My daughter has been reminding me all week—“Dad, the kids can’t wait to see you!” I promised I’d be there, to play board games and tell stories, to be the grandfather they look forward to. But as I sit at my desk, headset on, the phone lines light up. The new service we’re selling is complicated, and every other call is a barrage of technical questions. My script only scratches the surface, and my supervisor expects me to keep prospects engaged, answer their concerns, and not let a single lead slip away. I feel the pressure mounting—my family expects my presence, my warmth, my attention, while my job demands focus, patience, and quick thinking. My heart aches at the thought of missing my grandson’s laughter, but my mind races with the fear of disappointing my boss. The clock ticks closer to the gathering, and I’m caught between two worlds, each pulling at me with its own set of expectations.
